_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Risk Management Program, including the Emergency Response Program, was developed with the assistance of ALTEC Environmental Consulting, LLC and NRS Consulting Engineers, Inc.  The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for notification of the appropriate agencies and potentially affected members of the community.  In addition, it provides procedures for mitigating any releases that may cause harm to the community.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.



Since the facility must store 6,000 pounds to maintain a workable inventory of chlorine, it is required to prepare a Risk Management Plan.  To disinfect finished drinking water, the Camden Water Treatment Plant facility uses chlorine, which is considered hazardous by EPA and has a threshold planning quantity of 2,500 pounds under 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68.  The largest chlorine container at the facility is a one ton pressurized container.  The facility is a Program 2 facility due to the fact that there are public receptors within the worst-case scenario distance (eliminating Program 1) and they are not subject to OSHA regulation as a government entity (eliminating Program 3).



The primary purpose of this facility is to treat the water system by utilizing the regulated chemical chlorine.  Chlorine is injected into the water system by automatic feeders.  The feed system uses a vacuum demand system which means that with the exception of the gas demand regulator mounted near the gas supply valve on the container, the system is under vacuum.  



A worst-case scenario for this facility is specified in the EPA RMP guidance as the largest container emptying in 10 minutes.  Therefore, this would occur if 2,000 pounds of chlorine were released in 10 minutes or 200 pounds per minute.  No mitigating circumstances have been factored into this scenario.  It is assumed that the entire contents from the one-ton t

ank are released as a vapor.  In the years since RMP was implemented, EPA has developed guidance software, RMP*Comp, that can be used to determine impact areas.  The distance to the endpoint of 0.0087 mg/L for the worst-case scenario is 1.3 miles for a 200 lb./min release in urban terrain, according to RMP*Comp.



An alternative scenario was determined for this facility using knowledge of the system and EPA guidance documents.   The alternative scenario is based on the type of prevention system in place, and the release should be minimal. The vacuum demand system has been determined to be effective in preventing greater than small amounts of chlorine from being released.  The most likely scenario would be the development of a gasket leak between the container gas supply valve and the vacuum demand regulator. This amount of chlorine vapor release, according to RMP*Comp, would result in a distance to endpoint of approximately 0.1 of a mile, less than the distance to any public receptors.  



The Emergency Response Program was developed for the City of Camden and the surrounding areas with the assistance of NRS Consulting Engineers, Inc.  This program has been discussed with the Arkansas Office of Emergency Preparedness and the Camden Fire Department.  A representative of ALTEC Environmental Consulting, LLC visited on January 27, 2016.



There have been no accidental releases of Chlorine in the last five years.
